. 1) cold water storage tanks shall be arranged in one of following two ways 1) divided into two equal compartments (50/50 configuration as shown in figure h.9). this type of arrangement allows for one part of tank to be cleaned, disinfected, serviced, repaired, inspected, etc. while other in operation. this means that water supply pipe needs to be supplied to each part of tank, as set out in local requirements. to ensure that water flow provided when required, and that each tank section provided with equal volume of flow, water meter shall be installed on supply to each ball float or chain valve or 2) provided as two separate tanks that installed in parallel configuration. h 52 domestic water supply tanks shall be provided with lockable manholes. dimensions of manhole openings shall be sufficient to allow person to access tank safely for cleaning. openings shall be located away from public circulation areas and sources of contamination. 2) tanks shall be cleaned and sterilized after completion of work and prior to actual use of tank. all cold water storage tanks shall incorporate laboratory testing certificate stating its suitability for storing drinking water in accordance with dewa requirements ref. h.32. tank pump room h.5.5.5 pump room shall be of sufficient size to enable operation, maintenance and repair of various pumps that connect to tank. each pump set shall be installed on reinforced concrete base. 3) k 154 dubai building code part k villas cold water storage tanks k.10.2.5 cold water storage shall be provided to protect building against interruptions to incoming mains supplies and to ensure that water supply pressures can be safely maintained. 4) cold water storage may be provided utilizing single tank, single tank with central division or two separate cold water storage tanks. 5) 07 warning/overflow pipe 08 insulation (applicable to grp pre-insulated panel sectional tanks and steel tanks) k 155 dubai building code part k villas all tank interconnecting pipework and valves shall be configured to ensure balanced throughput of water through each tank mitigating risk of deadlegs and associated water stagnation. above ground cold water storage tanks should be constructed of pre-insulated glass- reinforced plastic (grp). backflow protection k.10.2.8 water systems shall be designed and installed to reduce risk of contaminating cold water supplies. in particular, requirements of water supply (water fittings) regulations ref. k.42 and classification of fluid category backflow protection shall be followed

. 1) for systems or applications not covered by this section, requirements and recommendations in following documents shall be met a) bs en 806 b) bs en 8558 c) hse approved code of practice l8 ref. h.25 and associated technical guidance documents ref. h.26 to ref. h.28 d) hsg272 ref. h.29 and hsg220 ref. h.30 and e) water supply (water fittings) regulations ref. h.31. h.5.2 water conservation and reuse h.5.2.1 compliance methods there two compliance routes for water use. a) elemental method all buildings shall conform to h.5.2.2. b) performance method calculation method may be employed for building which might not meet elemental requirements for water-efficient fixtures detailed in h.5.2.2. performance method shall use supporting calculations to compare annual water consumption of proposed building with that of reference building which meets elemental requirements of h.5.2.2. reference building shall be equal in shape, size and operational patterns to proposed building. compliance will be demonstrated if calculated annual water consumption of proposed building equal to or lower than annual water consumption of reference building. h.5.2.2 water-efficient fittings following water-efficient fittings shall be used a) fixtures with flow rate less than or equal to flow rates shown in table h.5 b) dual flush toilets c) automatic (proximity detection) or push-button faucets in all public facilities d) cisterns serving single or multiple urinals in public, commercial and industrial buildings with manual or automatic flush controls that operate based on usage patterns. only sanitary flushing shall be possible in event of building closure or shutdown (including overnight). faucets installed for specialized application may be exempted from meeting flow rates, subject to authority approval

. 1) concrete beam and slab deflection f.8.3.2 deflection limits for concrete slabs and beams shall be in accordance with section 24.2.2 of aci 318-19. value of incremental deflection (δinc) shall not exceed 20 mm after installation of partitions and finishes and shall be calculated in accordance with aci 435r and aci 318-19. incremental deflection limits do not consider pre-cambering which may be used to reduce effect of total deflection as deemed necessary. when evaluating deflection of concrete structures, detrimental effects of cracking shall be included by modifying stiffness (ei) for areas which have exceeded allowable tensile stresses. modified ei shall be chosen based on extent of cracking under design load. default stiffness modifiers given in aci 318-19 may be followed for regular structures subject to approximately uniform loads

. 1) f.5.8 sustainability sustainability standards shall be observed when designing structure, during building’s lifecycle. design of permanent works, together with construction operations shall fulfil resource efficiency standards in terms of materials. concrete mixes shall conform to f.11. f.6.2 structural concrete design basis f.6.2.1 design of concrete for structural purposes, including plain concrete and concrete containing non-prestressed reinforcement, prestressed reinforcement or both, shall conform to requirements of aci 318-19 including standards referenced therein. concrete strength f.6.2.2 concrete used for structural elements shall have compressive strength not less than fcu = 35 n/mm2 and f’c = 28 n/mm2. 2) concrete strengths lower than fcu = 40 n/mm2 may only be used when it can be demonstrated that lower strength suitable and accepted by authority, making sure effects of creep and shrinkage included. 3) aim to encourage industry to produce more sustainable concrete, eventually resulting in lowering impact of concrete construction on environment. it essential to balance specification of concrete for sustainability while ensuring other performance parameters optimized. engineers urged not to over-specify concrete strength and/or durability parameters and to permit flexibility in designing concrete mixes in way that encourages production of more sustainable concrete

. 1) h.11.7.3 digital services enabled approach digital services enablement resolves some of challenges and mitigates some of disadvantages of conventional approach. providing fundamental connectivity requirements in terms of infrastructure, systems and technology allows for future implementation of smart functionalities, use cases and downstream initiatives. these might include, but not limited to a) analytics b) alerts c) calculations d) dashboards and e) prediction models. 2) digital services enabled approach provides 1) building ot installed that can communicate via open iot protocols 2) consistent and standardized device naming and data structuring a) limited interoperability between systems, typically due to absence of 3) building ip network which can support suitable ip connectivity to devices and communication channels b) complexity and limited flexibility c) vendor lock-in, typically limited to single provider with difficulty to change d) convoluted naming of equipment and data, possibly requiring significant processing before any ingestion or analysis 4) open systems architecture

. 1) firefighting water tanks h.5.5.6 firefighting water tank and pump connection arrangements shall conform to ch. 9 of uae flsc ref. h.1. firefighting water tanks shall be located next to or below fire pump room, depending upon pump type selected. they shall conform to table 1.9, ch. 1 of uae flsc ref. h.1. firefighting water tank area shall have adequate drainage, and arrangement such that overfilling tank does not flood area and pump room, in accordance with table 9.3, ch. 9. of uae flsc ref. h.1. pump room and floor corridors shall be provided with drainage facility to drain dripped and leaked water or water flooded during firefighting operations. centralized firefighting water tank to serve multiple buildings in development permitted provided that buildings owned by one entity and maintenance of system managed and controlled as part of common area. size of tank shall be designed for more than one fire event simultaneously, to be agreed with dcd. 2) in addition, dcd does not permit emergency voice evacuation speakers inside emergency command centre. h 83 dubai building code part h indoor environment h.9.3 two-way communications systems h.9.5 fire protections systems two-way communication system for fire fighters shall be provided as required by, and designed to conform to, ch. 7 of uae flsc ref. h.1. fire protection systems shall be provided as required by, and designed to conform to, ch. 9 of uae flsc ref. h.1. two-way communication system for fire fighters shall be provided at all super high- rise buildings and following note design of firefighting water tanks or combined potable and firefighting water tanks covered in h.5.5.6 and h.5.5.7

. 1) fireplace stoves and room heaters h.4.16.2 stoves and solid fuel-type room heaters shall be approved by authority. they shall be installed in accordance with manufacturer’s installation instructions. fireplace stoves shall be tested in accordance with ul 737. solid fuel-type room heaters shall be tested in accordance with ul 1482. fireplace inserts shall be approved by authority in accordance with ul 1482. they shall be installed in accordance with manufacturer’s installation instructions

. 1) floor drains h.6.2.4 floor drains (see figure h.13) shall be installed in all building areas containing wet sanitary fittings or appliances (including kitchens, toilets, showers, cleaners’ rooms and ablution areas). 2) floor drains shall also be provided in mechanical plant rooms, waste rooms and garages, for plant drainage and for cleaning and washdown. all floor drain body and grating materials shall be specified to suit floor finishes within which they installed and imposed traffic loads to which they expected to be subject. waterproof seal shall be achieved between floor finish and edge of floor grating to prevent migration of water at this junction. 3) h 61 dubai building code part h indoor environment figure h.13 typical floor gully body and grating details in order to prevent trap seal evaporation, all floor drains shall be configured to receive wastewater flows from sanitary fitting or condensate connection from air-conditioning unit. where this not practicable, automatic drain trap primer shall be installed. floor gully with back inlet connection shall be utilized to receive waste pipe connections from these fittings. all floor drains shall have water seal at least 75 mm deep. waste pipe connections from bidets or urinals shall connect directly to discharge stack, not floor drain (see figure h.14). 4) all internal roof or paved areas that open to sky (that have catchment area of 16 m2 or less) shall be provided with floor drains to enable rainwater pipework to connect to nearest gully or waste discharge stack. all other areas that open to sky shall be provided with rainwater drain that provides free discharge to external area. for all air ventilation shafts, access doors shall be provided at lower level of well to facilitate cleaning and maintenance of rainwater drainage system. routing of rainwater pipework through sensitive areas of building should be avoided. sensitive areas might include, but not limited to 1) areas of architectural significance 2) pipework routes through areas of different ownership or tenancy and 3) areas where access to drainage pipework might be restricted. where routing pipework through these areas cannot be avoided, pipework installation shall be configured to mitigate risk of pipework leaks. this shall be achieved by using pipework materials that have limited pipework joints, or “pipe in pipe” installation techniques. 5) where greywater recycling proposed within building, separate discharge stacks shall be provided to drain greywater appliances such as showers, hand wash basins and baths (see figure k.96). wastewater flows from kitchen appliances should not be recycled. k 159 dubai building code part k villas k.10.3.2.3 floor drains floor drains (see figure k.97) shall be installed in all building areas containing wet sanitary fittings or appliances (including kitchens, toilets, showers and ablution areas). 6) figure k.97 floor drain connection detail to discharge stack in order to prevent trap seal evaporation, all floor drains shall be configured to receive wastewater flows from sanitary fitting or condensate connection from air- conditioning unit. where this not practicable, automatic drain trap primer shall be installed. floor gulley with back inlet connection shall be utilized to receive waste pipe connections from these fittings. all floor drains shall have minimum 75 mm deep water seal. waste pipe connection from bidets shall connect directly to discharge stack, not floor drain (see figure k.98). 7) all internal roof or paved areas that open to sky (that have catchment area of 16 m2 or less) shall be provided with floor drains to enable rainwater pipework to connect to nearest gully or waste discharge stack. all other open to sky areas shall be provided with rainwater drain that provides free discharge to external area. for all air ventilation shafts, access doors shall be provided at lower level of well to facilitate cleaning and maintenance of rainwater drainage system

column2: h.4.14.3 control systems for hotel rooms
column3: . 1) a) control systems shall be divided into sub-zones with independent controls for each building zones. controls for each sub-zone may vary based on zone’s exposure to sun or cooling load levels or by nature of usage. b) all independent control areas shall be able to 1) control temperature and 2) turn off systems when building or controlled part of building not occupied. c) central systems shall operate only when required by zonal control systems. h.4.14.2 building management system (bms) buildings having cooling load of 1,000 kw, or gross area of 5,000 m2 or greater, shall have bms capable of ensuring that building’s systems operate as designed and as required during all operating conditions. system shall provide full control and monitoring of system operations, apart from diagnostic reporting. system shall control chiller plant and hvac equipment as minimum, and record energy and water consumption. it shall also monitor and record performance of these items. h.4.14.3 h.4.14.3 control systems for hotel rooms hotel guest rooms shall incorporate automatic control systems that can turn off lighting, air-conditioning and power when room not occupied. each guest room should also incorporate automatic control system that can turn off air-conditioning when balcony door or window kept open. outdoor air ventilation shall be provided so that rooms can be kept well-ventilated and under positive pressure during unoccupied periods. ventilation shall be demand-controlled and capable of being activated by occupancy sensor or light switch. it shall be electrically interlocked

column3: . 1) h 23 dubai building code part h indoor environment h.4.10.2 minimum ventilation requirements for adequate indoor air quality all air-conditioned buildings shall be ventilated either mechanically or by mixed mode. they shall meet minimum requirements of ashrae 62.1, ashrae 62.2 and ashrae 170. occupancy density shall be determined in accordance with b.5.1 where possible. if occupancy not listed in b.5.1, outdoor air flow rate shall be based on default occupancy density values stated in ashrae 62.1, ashrae 62.2 and ashrae 170. indoor air quality h.4.10.3 air filters for general ventilation shall meet efficiency classification given in iso 16890-1 based upon particulate matter. 2) adequate space pressurization shall be provided to reduce moisture and contaminant transfer between adjacent spaces, thereby reducing contamination in occupied spaces and unwanted condensation and mould growth. space pressurization (via return, transfer or exhaust air) in space or location shall be designed in accordance to ashrae 62.2 or as approved by authority. k.10.1.6.2 minimum ventilation requirements for adequate indoor air quality outdoor air rates shall meet minimum requirement of ashrae 62.2

. 1) g.4.20.3 undervoltage (uv) relays with auto reset timer all air-conditioners and air-conditioning units/plants/ equipment installed within consumer’s installation shall be provided with uv relays that trip circuit breakers/contactors associated with these relays. tripping shall occur immediately and without any intentional time delay if supply voltage drops to or below 75% of nominal and remains at or below 75% for duration of 0.2 s. tripping shall not occur if supply voltage recovers above 75% within 0.2 s. uv relay’s auto-reset timer shall have adjustable time setting between 5 min and 10 min. circuit breakers/contactors associated with uv relay shall have auto-closing facility to restore supply to chillers/air conditioning units, after normalization of supply voltage, when relay reset automatically. auto-closing facility shall have motorized operation. auto-reset timer of uv relays shall be set at values specified in manufacturer’s schedules, approved by dewa, to suit individual installation. necessary provision for sealing may be incorporated in relay to restrict access for adjustments of setting. dubai building code part g incoming utilities uv relays with auto-reset timers shall normally be incorporated within respective air-conditioning unit/equipment or in their control panels. for normal air-conditioners, uv relays with auto-reset timers may be provided within consumer’s db for individual or group of air-conditioning units. prior approval shall be obtained from dewa for each application

rooms waste storage room(s) shall meet following requirements. 3) b) if it not possible to locate waste storage room(s) at ground floor level, they may be placed no more than one level down from ground floor, at first basement level, and shall conform to dcd requirements as stated in b.8.4. service elevator shall be provided to transfer waste and recycling to waste storage rooms(s) as required. if waste collection occurs on first basement level, it shall be designed with suitable access and clearance for waste collection vehicle as appropriate. c) access to waste storage room(s) shall be sufficient to facilitate easy entry, exit and manoeuvring of waste and recycling containers and waste collection operatives. where change in floor level exists, any longitudinal gradient falling away from storage location shall not exceed 8.33% (112). width of any passageway or access route which has to be passed through to reach waste storage room(s) should be of suitable width to allow waste containers to pass through easily, and not be less than 1.2 m. access paths should be free of kerbs and steps, and avoid difficult turns and bends. drop kerbs shall be provided where . 1) dubai building code part h indoor environment h.5.2.7 wastewater reuse if system installed for collection and reuse of greywater produced within building, or for use of treated sewage effluent (tse) from external source, following requirements shall be met. a) building shall be dual-plumbed for collection and recycled use of greywater. any pipes which transport greywater shall be colour-coded differently from pipes that used for potable water and be labelled “not suitable for drinking”. b) there shall be air break of not less than 25 mm between any potable water sources and greywater collection systems. c) greywater shall not be used for purposes where it will come into direct contact with human body. it shall be treated to standard required by authority. commercial car washing facilities shall recover and reuse at least 50% of their wastewater. 2) all wastewater reuse systems shall incorporate sampling points to enable water quality testing to be undertaken. h.5.2.8 potable water supplied by dewa shall not be used for heat rejection purposes. cooling tower water supply where cooling towers used, treated sewage effluent (tse), seawater or recycled water shall be used to meet water demand for all heat rejection purposes. secondary water sources shall be approved by dewa. separate totalising meter shall be fitted on water supply line to individual cooling towers. daily log of water use shall also be kept. water treatment plant will be required to remove impurities from cooling tower feed water and circulatory water. leaving cooling tower water untreated can lead to organic growth, fouling, and corrosion of system. this reduces efficiency and service life of cooling tower plant. type of water treatment system required depends on number of factors including a) type of cooling tower b) quality of water feed required c) cooling tower manufacturer’s requirements d) chemistry of make-up and circulation water e) whether or not blowdown will be treated for reuse in cooling tower and f) type of heat exchanger

. 1) all light fittings, wiring accessories and other electrical equipment in potentially hazardous atmospheres shall be selected in accordance with bs en 60079. 2) g.4.11 wiring accessories g.4.11.1 conduits and fittings high impact rigid pvc conduits and fittings shall conform to all relevant parts of bs 4607, bs en 60423 and bs en 61386. they shall meet following requirements a) be suitable for use at maximum ambient temperature of 48 °c b) not soften or suffer structural degradation at temperature of 70 °c c) be non-hygroscopic d) be heat-resistant. 3) k.9.1.9 wiring installations in hazardous areas all light fittings, wiring accessories and other electrical equipment in potentially hazardous atmospheres shall be selected in accordance with bs en 60079. 4) k.9.1.11 wiring accessories k.9.1.11.1 conduits and fittings high impact rigid pvc conduits and fittings shall conform to all relevant parts of bs 4607, bs en 60423 and bs en 61386. they shall meet following requirements a) be suitable for use at maximum ambient temperature of 48 °c b) not soften or suffer structural degradation at temperature of 70 °c c) be non-hygroscopic and d) be heat-resistant pvc conduits shall be provided with copper/brass terminals
